The ancients rosor-ted to this rhetorical expedient in the conviction that by so doing they could more vividly and objectiwely portray the feelings aud the motives by which - the principa] characters were actuated, and thus at the same time define the issues and reflect the spirit of the contending parties.²

Now, inasmuch as Tacitus was writing the life, not of a poet or scientist or philosopher, but oi a general who was himself helping to make history, it was inevitable that he should deal with πράξεις, which were the special province of the historiari, and thus the rhetorical exigencies of historical prose of which speeohes constituted an integral part, would be sufficient to justiiy their insertion in this strictly histori- cal portion of his biography. If the speeohes of Calgacus and Agricola are to be condemned as irrelevant in a genuine biography, the description of the battle, constituting as it did an equally integral feature of historioal narrative,8 should have met with the same condemnation‚ and yet no one has ever made the least objection to it in spite of its rhetorical and all but imaginative character.⁴
